refnamediv.refpurpose: arrays of arbitrary elements which grow automatically as elements are added

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Arrays are similar to standard C arrays, except that they grow automatically as elements are added.
Array elements can be of any size (though all elements of one array are the same size), and the array can be automatically cleared to '0's and zero-terminated.
To create a new array use g_array_new().
To add elements to an array, use g_array_append_val(), g_array_append_vals(), g_array_prepend_val(), and g_array_prepend_vals().
To access an element of an array, use g_array_index().
To set the size of an array, use g_array_set_size().
To free an array, use g_array_free().
Here is an example that stores integers in a GArray:

refsect2.title: g_array_new ()
refsect2.programlisting: GArray * g_array_new (gboolean zero_terminated, gboolean clear_, guint element_size);
refsect2.para: Creates a new GArray with a reference count of 1.

entry.para: TRUE if the array should have an extra element at the end which is set to 0
TRUE if GArray elements should be automatically cleared to 0 when they are allocated
the size of each element in bytes

refsect2.title: g_array_sized_new ()
refsect2.programlisting: GArray * g_array_sized_new (gboolean zero_terminated, gboolean clear_, guint element_size, guint reserved_size);
refsect2.para: Creates a new GArray with reserved_size elements preallocated and a reference count of 1. This avoids frequent reallocation, if you are going to add many elements to the array. Note however that the size of the array is still 0.

entry.para: TRUE if the array should have an extra element at the end with all bits cleared
TRUE if all bits in the array should be cleared to 0 on allocation
size of each element in the array

refsect2.title: g_array_ref ()
refsect2.para: Atomically increments the reference count of array by one. This function is thread-safe and may be called from any thread.
Since: 2.22

refsect2.title: g_array_unref ()
refsect2.para: Atomically decrements the reference count of array by one. If the reference count drops to 0, all memory allocated by the array is released. This function is thread-safe and may be called from any thread.
Since: 2.22

refsect2.title: g_array_get_element_size ()
refsect2.para: Gets the size of the elements in array .

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: Size of each element, in bytes

refsect2.para: Since: 2.22

refsect2.title: g_array_append_val()
refsect2.para: Adds the value on to the end of the array. The array will grow in size automatically if necessary.
g_array_append_val() is a macro which uses a reference to the value parameter v . This means that you cannot use it with literal values such as "27". You must use variables.

entry.para: the value to append to the GArray

refsect2.title: g_array_append_vals ()
refsect2.programlisting: GArray * g_array_append_vals (GArray *array, gconstpointer data, guint len);
refsect2.para: Adds len elements onto the end of the array.

entry.para: a pointer to the elements to append to the end of the array.
the number of elements to append

refsect2.title: g_array_prepend_val()
refsect2.para: Adds the value on to the start of the array. The array will grow in size automatically if necessary.
This operation is slower than g_array_append_val() since the existing elements in the array have to be moved to make space for the new element.
g_array_prepend_val() is a macro which uses a reference to the value parameter v . This means that you cannot use it with literal values such as "27". You must use variables.

entry.para: the value to prepend to the GArray

refsect2.title: g_array_prepend_vals ()
refsect2.programlisting: GArray * g_array_prepend_vals (GArray *array, gconstpointer data, guint len);
refsect2.para: Adds len elements onto the start of the array.
data may be NULL if (and only if) len is zero. If len is zero, this function is a no-op.
This operation is slower than g_array_append_vals() since the existing elements in the array have to be moved to make space for the new elements.

entry.para: a pointer to the elements to prepend to the start of the array.
the number of elements to prepend, which may be zero

refsect2.title: g_array_insert_val()
refsect2.para: Inserts an element into an array at the given index.
g_array_insert_val() is a macro which uses a reference to the value parameter v . This means that you cannot use it with literal values such as "27". You must use variables.

entry.para: the index to place the element at
the value to insert into the array

refsect2.title: g_array_insert_vals ()
refsect2.programlisting: GArray * g_array_insert_vals (GArray *array, guint index_, gconstpointer data, guint len);
refsect2.para: Inserts len elements into a GArray at the given index.

If index_ is greater than the arrayâ€™s current length, the array is expanded. The elements between the old end of the array and the newly inserted elements will be initialised to zero if the array was configured to clear elements; otherwise their values will be undefined.
data may be NULL if (and only if) len is zero. If len is zero, this function is a no-op.

entry.para: the index to place the elements at
a pointer to the elements to insert.
the number of elements to insert

refsect2.title: g_array_remove_index ()
refsect2.para: Removes the element at the given index from a GArray. The following elements are moved down one place.

entry.para: the index of the element to remove

refsect2.title: g_array_remove_index_fast ()
refsect2.para: Removes the element at the given index from a GArray. The last element in the array is used to fill in the space, so this function does not preserve the order of the GArray. But it is faster than g_array_remove_index().

entry.para: the index of the element to remove

refsect2.title: g_array_remove_range ()
refsect2.programlisting: GArray * g_array_remove_range (GArray *array, guint index_, guint length);
refsect2.para: Removes the given number of elements starting at the given index from a GArray. The following elements are moved to close the gap.

entry.para: the index of the first element to remove
the number of elements to remove

refsect2.para: Since: 2.4

refsect2.title: g_array_sort ()
refsect2.para: Sorts a GArray using compare_func which should be a qsort()-style comparison function (returns less than zero for first arg is less than second arg, zero for equal, greater zero if first arg is greater than second arg).
This is guaranteed to be a stable sort since version 2.32.

refsect2.title: g_array_sort_with_data ()
refsect2.programlisting: void g_array_sort_with_data (GArray *array, GCompareDataFunc compare_func, gpointer user_data);
refsect2.para: Like g_array_sort(), but the comparison function receives an extra user data argument.
This is guaranteed to be a stable sort since version 2.32.
There used to be a comment here about making the sort stable by using the addresses of the elements in the comparison function. This did not actually work, so any such code should be removed.

refsect2.title: g_array_index()
refsect2.para: Returns the element of a GArray at the given index. The return value is cast to the given type.
This example gets a pointer to an element in a GArray:

entry.para: the index of the element to return

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the element of the GArray at the index given by i

refsect2.title: g_array_set_size ()
refsect2.para: Sets the size of the array, expanding it if necessary. If the array was created with clear_ set to TRUE, the new elements are set to 0.

entry.para: the new size of the GArray

refsect2.title: g_array_set_clear_func ()
refsect2.para: Sets a function to clear an element of array .

The clear_func will be called when an element in the array data segment is removed and when the array is freed and data segment is deallocated as well. clear_func will be passed a pointer to the element to clear, rather than the element itself.
Note that in contrast with other uses of GDestroyNotify functions, clear_func is expected to clear the contents of the array element it is given, but not free the element itself.

entry.para: a function to clear an element of array

refsect2.para: Since: 2.32

refsect2.title: g_array_free ()
refsect2.para:
Frees the memory allocated for the GArray. If free_segment is TRUE it frees the memory block holding the elements as well and also each element if array has a element_free_func set. Pass FALSE if you want to free the GArray wrapper but preserve the underlying array for use elsewhere. If the reference count of array
is greater than one, the GArray wrapper is preserved but the size of array will be set to zero.
If array elements contain dynamically-allocated memory, they should be freed separately.
This function is not thread-safe. If using a GArray from multiple threads, use only the atomic g_array_ref() and g_array_unref() functions.

entry.para: if TRUE the actual element data is freed as well

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the element data if free_segment is FALSE, otherwise NULL. The element data should be freed using g_free().

refsect2.title: struct GArray
refsect2.para: Contains the public fields of a GArray.

entry.para: a pointer to the element data. The data may be moved as elements are added to the GArray.
the number of elements in the GArray not including the possible terminating zero element.
